pros: This campus is so big and segmented that you're likely to have a very different experience depending on what department you're in. My direct coworkers have generally been fantastic, though, and the workplace is generally casual with an "everybody pitch in" attitude. Lots of holidays and fairly good time off policies. If you're good at what you do, there are also ample opportunities to move up - some of the COO-level people in the administrative units started out at the Admin Assistant level.
cons:
Staff is constantly overworked, it's almost impossible to get rid of inefficient or incompetent people who pass their probationary periods which sometimes makes it look like you're fully staffed when in fact it's just the rest of you pulling for one. Constant budget cuts ALWAYS impact staff members and administrative departments first. Because it's a public university, you won't be paid market rate. Attempts to improve workflow processes tend to get lost in bureaucracy. 

There's still a "consensus" culture to UC, which is one of those things that sounds nice in theory but in practice means that any attempt at change will be met with open, obvious opposition. And often, if one person opposes, the entire attempt fails. There's a lot of inefficiency, but the structure and culture here very much entrenches that at the expense of the competent few, who receive mounting pressure and workload to make up the difference.

Fundamentally, Berkeley suffers from a lack of oversight despite an already bloated bureaucracy. There are amazing teachers and -- more commonly -- terrible teachers. job_title: Student Affairs Officer in Berkeley, CA
pros:
It's a state job, so you get all the perks of security, and union-like worker retention. Besides that, it's in a fairly nice area (at least as far as that goes in an urban area). UC is considered "prestigious" to many people. Since this is a public school, many of the students manage to be less self-involved and spoiled than you might find at a private school.

I don't really think that staff workers are overly busy during the day. There are a lot of bureaucratic meetings that take up time, if you're looking to shirk your day away.
cons:
It's a state job, so you get more than your share of lazy free-loaders, and union-like entitlements. It's really true that "crap rolls downhill" at UC Berkeley. If the regents need to cut 20% of the budget, as they  do this year, they'll cut 3% from upper management, 5% from student services, and 12% from staff salary. Besides that, the professors treat staff like garbage. In fact, if you don't have a PhD you ARE garbage to a lot of the people who work here. 

Also, it's usually expected that the good workers must make up for the lazy.

pros: people are great. the work environment is relaxed. there is nothing really wrong with berkeley as an employer. Well, that depends on what department you work in. As with most universities, there is a huge bureaucracy and sometimes it can be easy to get lost in behind all the red tape. But besides that, people are some of the most easy going you'll ever meet. It is definitely an easy gig if you are in the office most of the day. The campus is most definitely an enjoyable work environment. Feel stressed? take a walk outside in the woods. great.
cons: The bureaucracy. Sometimes it will take forever to get anything done. You have to wait for the higher ups to give the ok. And with that, sometimes they don't even know who you are which can definitely be a drag sometimes. The operations at berkeley are usually small, you work with a small group of people. So although the campus is quite large, you don't usually interact with many of the people in other departments--people usually do their own things. It can be lonely. I don't know how it would be in the corporate world, but you'd probably be around more people.

pros: The people you work with are awesome. I'm pretty close with the other TAs, and we hang out Friday night to de-stress from the tiring week. The other TAs, both undergraduates and graduate students, are really freaking smart and hardworking so it's awesome being around them.

-Berkeley spoils and fawns over the professors, which can really undermine supportive staff when enforcing policies and creating consistent structure for the students. 
-There is a lot of hand-holding, babysitting that comes with the new generation of students. Perhaps I'm old school, but I think part of the university experience is learning how to do and achieve life skills on your own-with the support of school staff, but not bending rules and cutting corners to do so.

job_title: Programmer Analyst II in Berkeley, CA

Hard to get fired since it's a public job.

State budget cuts are really hurting UC Berkeley.  There have been no raises or annual increases.  
The unions on campus are too powerful on campus and they keep whining.
I know other Programmer Analysts that technically don't know much, yet they are overpaid because they hopped on during the tech boom.  You never see salaries go down, so these lucky bastards get to keep their high salaries.

review_title: Serious attitude adjustment needed to stay sane here
pros: 8-5 weekdays, with no anticipation of overtime/after hours.  People expect you to have a life outside of work.  You do not lose your job or pet project for being down with a flu. In some departments, faculty "customers" show appreciation for a job well done.  Colleagues collaborate and help each other out during crunch time, which I hardly experienced in the private sector.
cons: Taking on more work and responsibility does not translate to a promotion or a raise. Certain managers go out of their way to "cheat" workers out of such opportunities.  Compensation beyond midpoint requires lengthy justification, which most managers will not do (unless you are the next of kin). Most in high management are experts at window-dressing, and discourage out-of-box thinking and any form of challenge to status-quo.  Bargaining units create great inequity and injustice.

pros: UC Berkeley is a top notch place to do research. Coming here you will be able to collaborate with extremely talented and driven people, on top notch research projects. cons: Not everyone at Berkeley is equally talented, or driven. So you have to choose carefully who you will work with, and what project you will work on. Add to this that  management on the side of the PIs is not ideal (they're too busy to keep track of what's really going on), you might find yourself getting less than you deserve, while others get more than they do (sometimes at your expense). So: at any level (grad student or PostDoc) choose carefully, don't get blinded by the UCB brand name

review_title: Accommodating and relaxing, if not a little dull

Lots of shifts are pretty easy to do and even the more "complicated" ones can be done relatively quickly once you've worked out a good system to get things done. Finishing early and natural downtime are common occurrence for certain shifts. Often receive free food and drinks from working at events.
cons: You are sometimes required to work at odd hours. While you can adjust your schedule, it is generally frowned upon to block off weekends, late nights and early mornings unless you have legitimate prior commitments. Low sense of fulfillment from work; often becomes mechanical and mind-numbing. The job does require some manual labor, but it isn't particularly strenuous.

pros: Because of an overall lack of accountability, plenty of time to work on personal business and outside interests.  Difficult to get fired.  Objective performance goals and reviews are talked about, but frequently don't happen.
cons: The academic senate (tenured professors) run the asylum.  This is a wacky bunch of ego centric wackos.  Most have never worked a day in outside industry and have no real world experience.  Professors treat everyone like they are grad students -there to be abused.   There is zero career growth.  Everyone gets the same performance review and (lack of) pay raise.

review_title: Bureaucratic Nonsense, But Some Amazing People
job_title: Administrative Assistant II in Berkeley, CA
pros: Some employees are extremely passionate about making a difference at this institution. Their work touches many lives including students, professors, researchers, and parents. It may not be the most efficient way to better education, but working here provides a means that is often hard to even find.
cons: Overwhelming inefficiency. There is a lack of people who are driven and take the initiative to better the system. However, there is always the looming question of whether their work to better the system is for naught, and if a system wide overhaul is what's needed. In the end, UC Berkeley is a place where many to fall into complacency and only a few ever make a difference.

review_title: Good learning experience, very low pay
pros: There is world-class academic research going on at UC Berkeley, and you're surrounded by very smart, motivated people. UC Berkeley is highly regarded in the sciences, so your reputation will be improved by working there. They are very serious about collaboration and will encourage you to pursue your research ideas and goals by working together with other people. The city of Berkeley is also a very vibrant place to live and work.
cons: They will pay you as little as possible. The salary for a PhD-level scientist is probably half that of any industry job in the area. UC Berkeley seems to believe that they're doing you a favor by letting you work there, so they don't need to pay you very much. The pay for many positions is even lower than other nearby UC schools, and they will try to claim that they don't have enough money to pay people more.

review_title: UCB senior management slammed for spending $3 million on consultants when work can be done by Faculty, Staff
pros: historical reputation, location on west coast
cons: Spending $3 million on consultants to do the work of Chancellor Birgeneau and Provost Breslauer. Chancellor & Provost paying consltants as they have lost the confidence and trust of Faculty and Staff. Troubled communications between Faculty Staff and UC Berkeley senior management prevents Faculty and Staff from identifying $150,000,000 in inefficiencies. Birgeneau and Breslauer using consultants to get back in touch with faculty and staff. Victims of Cal senior management incompetence are students and taxpayers of California.

review_title: Cal Summer Camps: a fun and educational experience, especially valuable for careers working with children
pros: The staff is all friendly and the director is great at running the camp - she works well with staff, parents, and children. There are multiple levels of staff members, allowing counselors to work their way up as they gain valuable skills in working with children and working as part of a team. You can request time off and also have access to the rec center!
cons: Pay is not very high unless you are working at a higher level (coordinator, etc.). Some positions require much more work and responsibility than others, even if the pay is similar. This job can be physically exhausting, but can also be really fun!

review_title: I am worried for public education
pros: There are some amazingly brilliant faculty and students here. If you choose your path carefully, you can have a good experience here as student, staff, or faculty.
cons: There are also some out-of-touch individuals whose relevance ended some time ago here. The explosion of over-paid administrators is terrifying. Faculty are not rewarded for spending time on administrative issues or governance, however, so it's their own fault that this cancer has taken over their University. The way adjuncts and lecturers are treated (and paid) is appalling.

review_title: Good name for your resume, but that is pretty much all you will get from this place.
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Berkeley, CA
pros: Plenty of freedom to work your own hours and execute your own ideas.  Other grad students and post-docs are really nice.  The bay area is a great place to live.
cons: PI is hands-off to the point of negligence.  There is no pressure to generate results, which might sound great initially, but instead yields an environment where the only people that care about progress are the grad students and post-docs.  Projects are poorly thought through and there is no overlap between projects, so lab members have to invent their own route to success using whatever means they can find from outside the lab.  No lab manager.  Money is spent on frivolous and duplicate supplies and then is unavailable for desperately needed purchases.  PI is absolutely unwilling to help with the job search.

review_title: They Don't Care About Grad Students
job_title: Computer Progamer in UC Berkeley, CA
pros: Amazing research, opportunities, extremely smart professors and fellow students, it's the best of the best, great facilities, beautiful campus, competitive salary (for grad student opportunities), really good health insurance, great city
cons: People in power hide behind the liberal image of UC Berkeley to avoid being fair and good employers. Little to no support for graduate students against their professors. Extremely competitive in an unproductive way. Professors and administration are very loose with the personal information of other students. Strong culture of misogyny. Student body overwhelmingly feels crushed by the attitudes of their superiors. General sense of lack of control over their career among students.

review_title: You'll just scrape by on salary, but the benefits and balance are great.
pros: U.C. Berkeley creates excellent work-life balance. The hours are reasonable, the campus is very pleasant, and the employees can get access to many facilities. Benefits for Post-Docs are among the best out there and are a major plus. In general, there is a lot of comraderie among staff, but it is only within close groups.
cons: Pay is terrible. Absolutely terrible. I know of no one from tenured Professor to grad student to administrator who was not underpaid. And it is very bureaucratic--it'll take 5 weeks to get a reimbursement. Administrative tasks are highly specialized and delegated to individuals who are not always present--thus if you need them you typically have to wait until Tuesday. Hiring is slow.

review_title: Very prestigious, very political, very well paid.
pros: The feeling of being part of a larger, more important project. Employees are more intellectually inclined and more culturally  attuned than in most organizations. Pay is great for mid-level people and no private employer would offer comparable benefits.
cons: The atmosphere is very political. Race and gender considerations are part of every employment decision. The tone is presumptively liberal with a great deal of smug self-satisfaction and no taste whatsoever for critically examining basic assumptions. The organization is extraordinarily bureaucratic with most employee energy going into checking the right boxes, not making any 'mistakes' and taking credit for anything good that happens anywhere in the vicinity of the job.

review_title: Cal is a great place to work- though every department is VERY different.
pros: Most department positions offer great work life balance, benefits and the knowledge that you are contributing to something greater than yourself.  Generally there are wonderful, like minded people as well.
cons: This depends greatly on the department, more so than at other "companies."  Many positions are dramatically underpaid compared to the private sector (or private schools), and some departments are very different in culture.  The core benefits are roughly the same for all, but the work life balance depends dramatically on the unit and job title.

job_title: Ph D Graduate Student Researcher & Instructor in Berkeley, CA
pros: The professors are the most accomplished in the world at their disciplines, and several of the graduate programs rank in the global top 5.
cons:
Working environment as a Ph.D. student varies wildly, but almost universally is miserable (see UC Berkeley graduate student mental health surveys; wildly enriched for depression). 

This is true in general for graduate schools, but Berkeley seems particularly bad (I also have experience with other universities due to being part of a joint program).
My take on this is that it's due to (1) lack of training for professors on how to lead teams and to manage, leading to competition where there could be cooperation and general toxic working environments and (2) way too many undergraduates and too little institutional support for them, sapping professors' and graduate student instructors' time.

review_title: It was a very pleasant experience with a diverse range of committed staff towards the goal of primary school education.
pros: The best part of working for UC Berkeley is the flexibility in schedule and hours. It was great to be able to coordinate the perfect schedule for the week that fits in nicely with my personal affairs.
cons: As most programs are mainly student run, at times, there does seem to be a lack of professional and strong structure to the overall program. There is also a very high turnover rate in supervisors since most staff are students as well.

review_title: I am a postdoc in biological sciences at Berkeley
pros: With the new union, the salary is commensurate with NIH levels.  There is a decent amount of support filling out health care options and learning about other benefits through HR and the VSPA.  They have just started a number of programs designed to help with academic job searches and applying for grants.
cons: The graduate union at Berkeley prohibits postdocs from teaching or TAing.  If you want additional teaching experience, you need to go outside the UC System (eg community college or SF state).  There is little to no support for jobs outside of academia.  There is little or no support if you are having conflicts within your lab or within the department (though think this is pretty standard for universities).  The career center is much more focused on the undergrads than on post grad job searches.

job_title: Graduate Student Instructor in Berkeley, CA
pros: Smart and motivated undergraduate students; a lot of leeway in determining the Reading & Composition syllabus for one's own class.
cons: UC Berkeley pays its Graduate Student Instructors (GSI's) less than a living wage. Rent here is around $800-1000 a month, and you get, after taxes, about $1500 a month. You can't buy groceries or books on that. It makes your life utterly miserable as a graduate student. You either have to take out a sizable loan every year, beg your parents for money, tap into savings or work two or three extra jobs, which doesn't leave any time to study. So: if you get a TA or GSI offer at another school, sit down and calculate the living costs there and compare them to those in Berkeley. If at all possible, don't come to Berkeley. You'll be sorry you did.

review_title: Top rate academically.  But be ready to compete with fellow grad students and don't expect much in terms of benefits.
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in UC Berkeley, CA
pros: Best of the best in science and engineering.  You can't ask for a more elite university when it comes to the sciences.  The research done here is at the cutting-edge of the state-of-the-art.  Berkeley is constantly pushing into new and unexplored territory, and you can be a part of this ride.  Funding at UC Berkeley is amazing in the science depts.  So your research will be well supported.  And the name recognition gives the grad students here an advantage in competing for prestigous fellowships.
cons: As such a preeminent institution, it is a highly competitive environment and can feel a bit cut-throat at times.  Nobody is here to baby you.

pros: Most people are not ambitious so you have easier competition when interviewing for higher positions.  Pension isn't what it used to be, but it is still a very strong benefit.  Some managers won't care if you take undocumented vacation.  Using sick time as PTO is commonly accepted.  Most positions will require about 20 hours per week to meet expectations.  Therefore on an hourly basis, compensation trumps anything in private sector.
cons: Very little incentive to excel (weak rewards for performance, very difficult to discharge employees once past probation, etc).  Everything moves very slowly.  Lots of wasted money on sloppy training programs and redundant tiers of leadership.  Senior leadership is in the business of self preservation.  Very political and rampant sexual harassment.

review_title: Great benefits and nice people, but disorganized
job_title: Administrative Assistant II in Berkeley, CA
pros: The benefits, vacation/sick leave and work/life balance are fantastic and there are a lot of employee perks. Also, the coworkers were great and the students are smart and easy to work with.
cons: Processes are disorganized and there is a lack of communication between departments who need to work together. It's very hard to advance in your career (and pay is low) unless you transfer into a different campus department than the one you work in. Another problem is that when people leave, if a department can't afford to hire someone new, the lower level people have to divide the work of the person that left and accomplish those tasks in addition to their current ones. Supervisors also end up having to supervise people whose tasks they aren't familiar with.

review_title: UC Berkeley - A good place to work hampered by poor senior management
job_title: Administrative Assistant II in Berkeley, CA
pros: UC Berkeley offers good pay for easy work. A friendly and diverse group of people work for the university, and they have a decent corporate culture. There are retirement plans offered for full time employees and the university health center is fantastic.
cons: Unfortunately the senior management in the housing and dining department doesn't make very good decisions and doesn't like to admit it. We have undergone multiple reorganizations in the past few years and each just added further confusion and difficulty to resolving issues our clients have.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Berkeley, CA
pros: This is a great option to help funding doctorate studies. However, its convenience strongly depends on the type of career path you are targeting. If you want to follow an academic path, working as a Graduate Student Assistant is better. It will let you developing a teaching background. On the other hand, if you are interested in acquiring research skills to work on research oriented positions later, the GSR is your best choice.
cons: You have to be careful in terms of the positions you work on. The best strategy is to do a GSR related with your own research. If you are not able to find one, try to work on something where you gain skills that you want to develop. If the GSR position does not meet any of this two requisites it can be a waste of your time.

job_title: IT Consultant in UC Berkeley, CA
pros: The amount of work and timing of deadlines were reasonable. Management was clear and unambiguous. Much less stress at a state institution like this compared to a company.
cons: Disorganization compared to other University of California locations. Little opportunity for creative input. The work I was doing was largely unnecessary from a systems analysis perspective, but it checked off boxes on their project plan. Getting set up as a vendor is a huge hassle due to insurance liability requirements. Going through an existing vendor cuts the salary in half to $45-$50/hr.

review_title: Project Crew Lead Maintenance....Aka...garbage hauler + furniture mover....a joke.
job_title: Project Crew Building Maintenance in Berkeley, CA
pros: Great health care benefits.  Retirement system is fair.
cons:
Project Crew maintenance technician in the RSSP dept. (Residential & Student Housing....Technicians were over worked. Position advertised as a lead maintenance tech, but jobs consisted of doing all the dirty work, that other trades did not want to do.  Load dump trucks and do trash runs, empty out  furniture to hundreds of student dorms, so carpet companies can re-carpet.
Exposure to bed bugs, heavy (un-realistic lifting and unloading heavy items)
Managers that absolutely had no consideration for your well being, because UC Berkeley is self insured when it comes to workmanship compensation.
Almost every trades person goes out on workmanship comp. at some point or another.
No growth opportunities.
You will be charged $$ for parking your car.
Stupid managers, that are disconnected with their staff.
Old timers that give new employees a hard time, while they goof off...

pros: There is an incredible community at Berkeley of intelligent and motivated students and professors. I feel honored to work with them.
cons: Its a large school and can be overwhelming without knowing anyone coming in. Its important to join clubs the first semester.

review_title: used to be a better place to work.
pros: the intellectual environment is great!  i have the opportunity to work closely with professors and their research, and to sit in on classes i'm interested in.  there is an energy and passion that isn't always apparent in the private sector.  work/life balance is very good, with a lot of flexibility in schedule and work style.
cons: low comparative pay, advancement opportunities are lacking.  budget issues are bringing down staff morale, especially when the salaries and benefits for professors keeps increasing, yet staff salaries remain flat.  this model is not sustainable.  relative isolation in job duties, since so much is decentralized.  things are done differently in many departments and units on campus.

review_title: Stimulating atmosphere in spite of the best efforts by the administration
pros: The University provides a great atmosphere with a lot of stimulating discussion.  There are a lot of activities in which to participate and school's name provides a lot of cachet.
cons: The administration, thanks to budget cuts and some strange priorities, generally does not treat academics very well.  Lots of "amenities" are not offered.  For example, they turn off the hall lights after business hours and it is awfully dark in the hallway (I have to use my keychain light to find the door).  Also, we don't have phones in our offices, supposedly as a budget-saver.

review_title: The people who work here are great and very dedicated.
pros: It was a fun place to work. The staff are located in the Alumni House on the beautiful Berkeley campus. I had control over the programs I managed. The staff who stay at CAA are some of the most dedicated people.
cons: The experience depends heavily on the current Executive Director. CAA is always in financial trouble because it's completely self-sustaining. Some people leave because they feel they aren't being compensated for the work they do.

review_title: Working as an Office Mgr in a Berkeley Natural History Museum
pros: The health benefits and pay are great, the people are fun and interesting. Not many cons - plenty of room for growth. I left primarily because I wanted to prioritize other career options (technical editing).
cons: As I said, there weren't many cons at my position that weren't related to the organization being in a period of transition (for multiple things/roles). If you don't like working overtime for events (they don't pay you overtime because you work on salary), that'd be the main reason for passing on an admin position in BNHM.

pros: Solid pay, many opportunities for mobility within the university, great benefit and pension program, inclusive culture, autonomy within departments, so many resources for staff from tuition reduction free classes, health and wellness, ergonomics, classes on financial management, how to buy a home, etc.  Partnerships with major companies like bart discount, free Marco Polo or Masonic status with airlines, etc.  Free Microsoft software, etc. Civic minded campus, strong sense of community.
cons: departments work in silos, little innovation, inefficient/ineffective operating models, no support from public funding such as state or federal.  so slow at incorporating basic foundations such as google platforms, electronic timesheet, IT system, etc.

review_title: UC Berkeley is a great university
job_title: Grauduate Student Researcher in Berkeley, CA
pros: Good reputation, especially for graduate school. Excellent and helpful staff and faculties. Good atmosphere, nice campus, lots of resources, etc. Berkeley is a very very nice town, close to San Francisco - one of the best cities in the world, close to the sea, close to mountains... weather is always nice... many good restaurants around... basically, you can find everything you want here. The university itself has lots of diversity. It is fun to get to know people from other countries, get to know other cultures..
cons: Pay is lower than private universities, but is enough, at least for graduate students... hard to find parking space, even after you pay a lot, there is no guarantee that you can have a space every morning...

pros: Cutting edge research, Excellent hardware experience, Great opportunities to follow your own path and develop your own research, Berkeley is great and San Francisco is better so the location alone makes up for most of the issues.
cons: Very little management, not many senior staff available (at least within my dept), postdocs don't have great vacation etc. The Postdoc union is trying hard to improve the rights of postdocs. The lab is not in very good condition - very old and outdated and in need of a makeover. The acedemic mindset is alive and well here, which is  not always a good thing, especially when it comes to administration and management.

pros: Berkeley has some of the best resources for doing research and the professors are world renowned. I worked in the Caldwell Lab as an undergrad researcher and am currently working on a stable isotope research project to map out the ecological food webs of octopuses found at Catalina Island. The position definitely gives you experience in dissections, freeze drying, and other various lab tech skills necessary to extract the data from the samples.
cons: I've had difficulty getting my own research project in the Caldwell Lab. The professors are so busy and have so many students that they won't always be available.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in UC Berkeley, CA
pros: Berkeley engineering is very research-oriented and has professors who are not only top in their research field but also great as advisers. You will be surrounded by students who have the same passion and professional staff who can be great support.
cons: I guess for PhD students, from time to time, there is pressure to generate new ideas and push the research work through. Another thing would be because Berkeley is an academic environment, you do feel the gap when you graduate and want to go into real industry.

review_title: Great University hampered by politics and bureaucracy.
job_title: Programmer/Analyst II in UC Berkeley, CA
pros: Great University atmosphere and college town feel. The students, faculty and staff who are proud to be there. Everyone can gather around school pride. Many opportunities to get involved in campus events and activities, and being UC Berkeley these encompass a wide range. Downtown Berkeley has both aspects of a bustling city and a small town feel with all of the unique local businesses.
cons: Office politics are rampant and you always have to worry about hurting peoples feelings. Newer hires are often overqualified for their position and thus do not feel challenged. Long term employees are very resistant to change, even if for the better. Outdated SOPs.

job_title: Systems Administrator IV in Berkeley, CA
pros: Great co-workers, stimulating environment, excellent peer communication.  Generally hard working people of vastly diverse backgrounds.  Management seems non-intrusive and generally supportive (i.e. jaded from working here 20 years, yet realistic)
cons: The pay could be a little more (though I bargained close to what I was making in the commercial world) but if you're experienced you can write your own ticket.  Some folk seem to hang around ad infinitum just waiting for their retirement date to come.  But generally most workers are very conscious of why they are here and what they are doing.

pros: Professional development is superb for technical staff; benefits are good but not the best as compared to other Bay Area employers. Chances and opportunities to work with many different technical standards.
cons: Poor budgeting (almost embarrassingly poor) leading to staff layoffs. Redundancy in I.T. - "One IT" is a myth. Some IT teams do not get along with other IT teams. Money is wasted on scores of consultants on large projects forcing smaller IT shops to severely cut back. Rather sad.. A LOT of favoritism too on staff that gets retained -- newer, more current folk are told "good bye!"

review_title: Proactively find opportunities and make it work for you
pros: UC Berkeley has incredible researchers in so many fields. Being able to learn from and work with professors in many different areas has helped me thrive as an interdisciplinary researcher. I have been fortunate to find professors who really care and have really helped me.
cons: Everyone at Berkeley is overworked and really busy and probably won't answer your email. Actively seek out mentors for different areas you need help with. Meet professors by taking their classes and even then go the extra mile to build a relationship. Try to get invited to dinners or other networking events. Always be pleasant and diplomatic so you can build your reputation across the university. Keep a side hustle going so you can pay rent.

review_title: Good place to work in your 40s and 50s
job_title: Programmer/Analyst III in UC Berkeley, CA
pros:
Professional, respectful, supportive environment
Extremely low stress job
Lots of independence
Never work more than 40 hours a week
cons:
Pay for engineers is way below market
Not a lot of interesting engineering problems to solve if you work in a non-academic department
Sometimes hard to stay busy
Co-workers are not the cream of the crop

pros: Cal is an exciting, innovative university. The energy is palpable. There is always something going on. Students are engaged and passionate. (some) Professors are outstanding teachers and thinkers.  I'm really proud of the diversity and educational equity efforts of the university, across all levels, spheres, and fields.
cons: Unfortunately, at Berkeley, the challenges of a public institution are real: budget cuts, raised tuitions (effecting which demographics now are prioritized), increased staff/employee responsibilities for same or less compensation, an increased dependency on graduate student instructors and adjuncts, etc. Also, because of the pressure on professors to produce, I think that in prioritizing their time, teaching (undergraduates) is neglected responsibility. Despite the high volume of intellectual activity, there is little exchange or collaboration, making Cal an isolating place to be, at least at the graduate level.

job_title: PhD Candidate In Biophysics in Berkeley, CA
pros: My program is small and extremely supportive. That is not true of larger departments. The fact that we in Biophysics have had the same program coordinator for many years is a real asset. She knows the way much off the system works, and is happy to help the graduate students.
cons: The expectation for graduate students to cover costs and be reimbursed is the definition of misuse of human resources, but personally does not bother me. The bureaucracy is as bad as you might expect, and the turnover for those that manage my affairs in human resources and payroll is remarkable — almost every year.

review_title: The Lair of the Bear provides a very fun and fulfilling wok experience, providing hands on customer service experience.
job_title: Lair of the Bear Staff in Pinecrest, CA
pros: The best things about this job are the lifelong friendships, customer service experience and personal growth you gain from living and working in the woods for the summer.  The camp grounds, new campers arriving each work and the fellow staffers make the experience amazing.
cons: Some of the most challenging things within this job would be listening to and trying to appease the campers when they are not happy about the current customer service they are receiving. The hours can be long and tiring and the fast-paced customer service you must provide daily can make the experience challenging.

review_title: The best place for a postdoc
pros: The work environment is great. Berkeley is the best place on earth to live in. The level of science in which you are amerced is one of the highest in the world. The combination of a thriving research environment with an okay salary for a cost of living plus life in the bay area makes it the best place for a postdoc. The work frame is very flexible.
cons: Simply no cons!!! Everything depends on your PI, for good and for bad. This is the way for every postdoc, not  just specific to Berkeley. No real summer. The salary could be better (as usual). The rent is too high too. Every postdoc comes the an end and you need to leave.

review_title: Great for Research but Poor Facilities and Affordability
pros: U.C. Berkeley is an excellent place to do cutting-edge research. In terms of Chemistry and Molecular Biology, existing infrastructure and peoples' willingness to collaborate enable a great variety of projects to be carried out in many fields. Beautiful campus, located in a major tech hub.
cons: Chemistry facilities are ageing and require frequent repairs. Facilities services resources are over-taxed and repairs often take a long time to be carried out. Temperature control in some areas is poor resulting in work-spaces that are uncomfortably hot / cold. Housing in the area is very expensive and difficult to afford on a postdoc salary. Limited parking provided by the university and area traffic make it difficult to commute from far away.

review_title: Great benefits, lower than average salary, no opportunity for advancement, nepotist management
pros: Access to libraries, proximity to decent eateries, very good benefits,
cons: Managers / directors / assistant deans condone themselves with a high attitude of self-entitlement and treat their jobs as side kicks.

review_title: Good people, disjointed administrative processes, lack of tools to succeed on the job
pros:
- co-workers mean well and work hard
- great location (beautiful Berkeley campus, many restaurants, great urban culture)
cons:
- budget cuts make very basic needs (eg office supplies, custodial services) go unmet
- bureaucracy: middle management ill-informed about administrative processes but employees not allowed to contact offices directly to get employee needs met (related to HR and financial reimbursement)
- don't hold people accountable for action items and simultaneously require them to get permission from 5+ people for every action
- student services require you be available 24/7

review_title: Worked as a Legal Assistant at the Law School
pros: Government job, so the benefits and retirement plans are very nice. The hours are nice and flexible, which helps with commuting. Steady flow of work that keeps you busy. A decent amount of sick/vacation time available. The work life balance is pretty easy to maintain.
cons: The work is almost all clerical. The job title should be changed to administrative assistant. Asked to wear a lot of hats without any sort of benefit for doing so. Very little interaction with direct supervisor and almost no interaction with management. Due to budget understaffing is an issue

review_title: Cutting-edge research with a side of bureaucracy
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Berkeley, CA
pros: The research here is absolutely cutting-edge, with some of the brightest, most innovative and creative people in the world. There are experts in nearly every field and subject here, and the work environment is collaborative and supportive, especially in the College of Chemistry.
cons: There is a lot of bureaucracy here - if you need something done, you're likely to have to go through several offices and staff members before you can find someone who actually has the power to help you out. The Chemistry department has a large number of grad students, so sometimes it's easy to feel lost within the department.

review_title: Great part-time student job with flexible hours.
job_title: Residential Computing Consultant in Berkeley, CA
pros: For a student job, working as a Residential Computing Consultant is great.  The hours are flexible, and for many of them you have the opportunity to work on homework or other studies while you simply wait on a technical support line or work in a residential computing center.  A highly recommended job, make sure to spend time on the application and prepare for the interview, as in some semesters the application process can be very competitive.
cons: You can get paid more for doing similar IT work on campus, though the hours are not nearly as flexible.

pros: Working at UC Berkeley means I make a difference everyday. I contribute to something larger than myself by contributing to an instution that makes the world a better place. The benefits are outstanding, and having work-life balance is actually possible.
cons: I'm not paid as much as I would be in the private sector, and I often work using antiquated technology.  Faculty is king, and the contributions of staff are more likely to be overlooked than praised and celebrated.

review_title: This job allowed me to do an unpaid internship on campus before taking a better job off campus (better for me).
pros: Great environment. Terrific entry-level fund-raising/sales job for Cal students.  Directly across the street from campus.  Good pay with opportunity to earn more!  I highly recommend you check it out if you're looking for flexible job at Cal.  Helpful managers and trainers. Get to speak with interesting Cal alumni!
cons: Not a career job (except for 2-3 people).  Shifts for new employees only 5 - 10 PM.  No benefits.  Not much opportunity for anything but basic pay, some commission and flexible shifts.

review_title: Unlivable wage, poor supervision, horrific job prospects, bureaucratic, but prestigious
pros:
* prestige
* some remarkable students
* flexibility in course design and pedagogy
* pretty campus, interesting culture
cons:
* the stipend (in the humanities, at least) is not enough to afford safe living standards in the Bay Area
* supervisors treat graduate students as annoyances rather than assets for their research and legacy
* the job market is atrocious and the university does not prepare us
* the university bureaucracy will drive you crazy
* very little support if your co-teacher isn't doing their share
* drugged by colleague, sleazy encounters with faculty
* very little community because everyone is overwhelmed

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Berkeley, CA
pros: Speaking from the life sciences perspective (no experience with humanities, athletics), Berkeley's top faculty push their labs to move fields forwards. 25 Nobels are not a mistake, and the faculty that enjoy teaching are the best bar none. The majority of the graduate students are motivated and excited about their work.
cons: As a public institution, Berkeley is subject to budget concerns that are less present at private schools. Administrative processing can take much longer than necessary and adds burden to faculty that are not good at managing everything on their own (however that inability to multitask might be a fault of the individual faculty, not the university) , due to far fewer administrative staff relative to faculty than what I have experienced at other research institutions.

review_title: Good, fair employer with opportunities for other jobs and flexibility for students
pros: As a student worker I was treated fairly and there were flexible hours, pay was fine for the type of work involved, lots of independent work and easy to contact supervisors and switch shifts. Efficient and a decent student job.
cons: Pay was kind of low considering the hours worked (late shifts for my type of job), even though a monitor is not very skilled work there should be more considerations for how late the shifts are for students. The raises for staying on are also quite low, about 25-50 cents more per hour, should be up to a dollar higher for those of us who are trained and show consistent commitment to the job.

review_title: I worked as a student library employee in Main Stacks.
job_title: Student Library Employee in Berkeley, CA
pros: Hours are flexible, the workers are other students and a friendly atmosphere is encouraged, and it's really easy to get to in-between classes. There is always work to do if you want extra hours. If you just want to work without socializing, you can just listen to music and work at your own pace.
cons: The supervisors are also students and there's a certain amount of favoritism in who gets promoted to those positions. It was also extremely difficult to get a position at the reception desk unless you were in that crowd. While I was there security was also non-existent and my wallet was stolen from my bag while I was working. It's not the most intellectually stimulating job.

pros:
- a sprinkle of co-workers who are passionate about education
- good health coverage benefits
- close access to Bart
- knowledgeable co-workers
- technology team is always working hard at perfecting processes and improving online courses
cons:
- higher management severely lacks emotional intelligence
- employees who have been there for years are comfortable and crabby in their positions
- no chances to advance 
- broken processes
- no performance guides or outlines
- no opportunities for salary bonuses or increases (except for bonus nomination, which is not always fair, as it is decided by a committee who have no direct knowledge of the nominees)

review_title: UC BERKELEY EXTENSION: DO NOT WORK IN THIS DEPARTMENT UNDER ANY CIRCUMSTANCES
pros:
-The people at UNEX are generally nice people. 
-Benefits were good. 
-Work-life balance was fine. I was a UC/Bechtel employee before I moved to UNEX, and the work-life balance at UNEX was literally the same.
cons:
-Awful facilities.
-No room for career advancement.
-I was asked to spy on a team member and report back to my director. I assumed others were asked to do the same to me.
-Wildly political. Management makes decisions based on political impact instead of mission.
-Work was often stolen and pawned off as someone else's. 
-The mission and vision practiced by UNEX are consistent with UCB's.
-HR was almost non-existent.
-Total lack of transparency. 
-Lots of infighting and backstabbing between internal departments and academics.
-The highest turnover rate I have ever seen for people under any kind of middle management.
-Basically, nothing is good about working at UNEX.

pros: Working among some of the worlds most ambitious, creative, accomplished, and brilliant people.  Access to top-notch facilities and resources.  Location, location, location.
cons: Tenure, the scientific publishing industry, and the antiquated and more-or-less feudalistic apprenticeship paradigm of Ph.D. training, among many other structural problems in modern science, converge to create numerous problems for Ph.D. students and post-docs.  Among them are low pay and very little support for students interested in non-academic careers.

review_title: Lively community and interesting coworkers. Great opportunities to explore what research is like.
job_title: Student Assistant III in Berkeley, CA
pros: The chance to collaborate with researchers in a variety of disciplines and departments. During my time as a student, I did research in 3 departments and had a positive experience in each position. If you don't have previous experience, you can start as an unpaid volunteer and transition to a paid position with time.
cons: As an undergraduate student, jobs are more difficult to get if you don't have work-study. Many campus positions are for work-study only - these tend to be administrative type jobs and are paid fairly well for a student salary. When I first looked for a job, I checked Callisto (which fortunately does have some non work-study positions.)

pros: I loved working at UC Berkeley as a Postdoc. It is a very active research campus with interesting things going on everywhere.
cons: The lab environment is fairly isolated, and the network you develop is all academic, which can be a  liability when searching for private sector jobs.

pros: I was paid very well, and I worked directly under the IT manager as an IT assistant. It was fairly low-stress, and it was a good part time job to have while studying. Management was very sympathetic towards my heavy workload. I was a double major in Astrophysics and Applied Mathematics. I was always reassured that I could take time off to catch up on school work.
cons: It was clear that more help was needed. More employees need to be hired at the management level. My IT manager was the only full-time IT employee for the entire building. All of the burden fell on him, and it was very unfair.

pros: Laid back work culture, lots of vacation time per year, good benefits, and a well established higher academic setting.
cons: Lacks promotional opportunities, really low pay, and lots of inequality within the department with salary structure and work obligations (some people work really hard and get paid less than others that don't work hard that get paid well).

review_title: Great benefits, stable job, but little room for career development
pros: Employees are treated with respect. Good work-life balance. Great benefits. Everyone is friendly. Relatively laid back culture. I also enjoy working with students. Very creative place for research. Collaborative and sharing research culture in the life sciences. Among the best research facilities in academia.
cons: Little emphasis on career development and advancement and promotions for research employees outside the faculty ranks. Obviously, pay is lower than private sector. Professors are brilliant scientists, first and foremost, but sometimes have little interest in management issues and skills.

job_title: Administrative Assistant III in Berkeley, CA
pros: The people that share your space were, on the most part, incredibly nice and thoughtful people.  And generally committed to their work.  There are always opportunites to make lateral moves, and even steps up in a career path.
cons: Some of people were a little set in their ways - what you might call bogged down in legacy - "ths is the way we've done it in the past, and that means this is the only way to do it."  You are somewhat pigeoned into a particular career path, and it is harder to make a start in something a little different.

job_title: Human Resource Coordinator in Berkeley, CA
pros: Great benefits, well-developed and new offices (it is Berkeley, after all), lots of opportunities for growth and upward mobility. Also diversity, they strive to hire lots of women and underrepresented ethnic and racial groups.
cons: No room for individual creativity and ideas, corporate atmosphere, stiff, chain-of-command type leadership, creepily quiet offices, old people, bad coffee, lots of ass-kissing to maintain reputation.

review_title: Used to be a Great Place
pros:
Management whose mission was to support the university
Tools to do your job
Flex Hours
Health care benefits and pension plan
Cooperative team
cons:
When funds were tight, management was so used to having free flowing money, they had no idea how to operate on a restricted budget
Money kept flowing to the faculty, whether they deserved it or not
Hiring people who had no idea how to manage, lead or inspire

review_title: A great place to work.... mostly.
job_title: Student Affairs Officer/Career Counselor in Berkeley, CA
pros: I love the interactions I have with such a very diverse staff and quality of students.  The campus is beautiful (except when it's under construction.... which is most of the time), and there are a variety of opportunities to get involved on campus.  I'm fortunate to work in an office that allows for a lot of collaboration across departments.
cons: Compensation is getting better, but really, for the work we do, it's tough to get 'market rate' here.  There are a lot of inconsistencies on campus in departments, so while my experience is mostly great, someone across campus who does similar work as I do, will have a completely different viewpoint.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Berkeley, CA
pros: The faculty here are amazing, I have had the opportunity to learn from some of the best in their respective fields and I have learned so much.  Also amazing technical staff.
cons: The administration and bureaucracy can be crippling at times.  They tore down my office with a promise to build a new office space three years ago.  They have since torn down our temporary offices (don't have an office now) and they have run out of money to build the new offices.  Don't expect the university to actually deliver on renovations or to be particularly helpful.

review_title: Great place to have gone to grad school, but it's not pretty while you're there.
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Berkeley, CA
pros: There is excellent recognition of the berkeley name and the talent of researchers coming out of the hard science graduate programs.
cons: The politics and rigamorole of a large research university quite often get in the way of actually accomplishing the expressed goals of the university and program.

review_title: Perfect student job for Cal students seeking part-time employment.
job_title: Event Staff in UC Berkeley, CA
pros: The ASUC offers very friendly employment terms for students, making the appropriate accommodations for class scheduling and taking strong efforts to hire Work-Study participants. The work environment is student-centered, with most of the staff employed to put on events that are run by and for student groups. Management has good working relationships with all student employees and promotion is fairly predictable. Compensation is on par with most other student jobs.
cons: Event management can be hectic and client relations are often challenging for the staff to maintain. There can be tremendous amounts of downtime for the employees that is not effectively managed.

review_title: Great Non-Proft organization located on the Berkeley Campus.
job_title: Human Resources Coordinator in Berkeley, CA
pros:
Relaxed academic atmosphere.
Great location on the Cal campus.
Clear company directive (supporting students and alumni).
Fun company activities (tail gate parties, summer camps, fund raisers).
Good place to start a career.
cons: Working at a non-profit means tight budget and limited resources. You are always aware of the company working on less money than it needs to achieve all its goals. But at least you know where the money is spent and its a good cause.

review_title: Academically leading the pack, but operationally mired in the past
pros: Contributes to the mission of excellence in public education, allows flexibility and work/life balance
cons: Some benefits lacking, little innovation, silo mentality, inefficient operations, change resistant

review_title: Amazing school but OK work environment
pros: I've met many amazing people here and I worked part time in the Dining Commons.
cons: The position I had was almost more of a commission-based gig (I came in when needed which was only once a month) and there were several times where I was asked to come in when the DC was closed and no one was onsite to open the doors. There was a lot of lack of communication between my team and the upper management in terms of general work policies (where to keep supplies, where to wash up, even basic training and information about how to use the facility) and I think that's what frustrated me the most about this job.

job_title: Human Resources Business Partner in Berkeley, CA
pros: This was a wonderful place to learn and grow as an HR professional. They were great with ensuring there was a work/life balance when needed.  I never had to beg or perform a miracle to re-arrange my work schedule when needed to ensure I could meet my family obligations.  Loved the paid holidays and shut down around Christmas.
cons: Heavy turn over made it difficult to gain any traction with your clients.  It also made it difficult to get additional training and mentoring when needed.

review_title: Intellectual freedom, but not enough structure
pros: I was given the freedom to create my own research program and determine how I spent the majority of my time. I had access to world-class faculty and facilities, with an incredible number of campus events, both professional and for fun.
cons: I received very little guidance in my work, and my office space was not very appealing (small, old furniture, outdated computers and other equipment). With the recent budgetary crisis, the general atmosphere around campus was pretty bleak--everyone was afraid of losing their job, or having their salary greatly reduced.

review_title: Fantastic to get paid to pursue your interests
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Berkeley, CA
pros: Very flexible environment where you get paid to work on your graduate research at half-time, but no one tracks your hours. You do your work, order reasonable supplies as needed, and write up the results. Pressure to produce only when corporate sponsors are expecting results, but you set the timeline. Health benefits and graduate tuition are paid as part of employment, adding about $10,000 to the value of the job.
cons: Not a structured environment, so you must be a self-starter and able to function independently. If you need something from another part of the system, it can sometimes take a while to process, so you must plan ahead for bureaucratic delays.

pros: Berkeley is a wonderful place to do research science.  The atmosphere is laid back.  The research resources are exceptional.
cons: There is a lot of support for postdocs, but sometimes it is difficult to figure out how to get that support.  The area is expensive and it can be difficult to raise a family on a postdoc stipend.  Seminars are often in the evenings which is very difficult for parents with children to attend.

review_title: It was a positive experience overall, but the organization's effectiveness is encumbered by campus and office politics.
pros: The organization views training as an ongoing process.  It offers access to hundreds of online training modules to improve job performance.  It also offers access to its regular university courses free of charge.  There seems to be room for advancement of you want it.
cons: The  health insurance choices are limited. There is no longer a pension. Instead, there is a mandatory retirement savings program, which deducts 7.5% from each paycheck.

job_title: Residential Computing Consultant in Berkeley, CA
pros: I learned a lot while working as an RCC. It really sparked and catered to my interest in computer science. Plus, there were a ton of free events and food, and the hours were for flexible. It's a great place to work when you're attending Cal.
cons: None that I could really think of. Again, it's a great place to work. Maybe the pay could be better, but it's pretty fair.

review_title: Former employee, ready to move on!
job_title: Student Affairs Officer in Berkeley, CA
pros:
+ Great benefits
+ Great students, very motivated
+ Staff development opportunities are out there if you look
+ Opportunities for staff to get involved in other areas (if you have an understanding manager)
cons:
- Confusing and stressful time of layoffs
- Furlough days implemented, salary cuts
- Bureaucracy stunted new developments, makes progress slow
- Overworked (and underpaid)
- Student affairs departments, although similar in nature and purpose, operate in silohs and across campus. Unless you initiate a partnership, staff work as divided sections of a whole. (Not an ideal comprehensive model for student affairs).

review_title: strong postdoc union hugely improved working conditions
pros:
The postdoc union at Berkeley has made amazing headway on benefits. They're the best I've seen across the country:
-4-5 weeks vacation time
-good and affordable health benefits ($10-20 for 1 individual/month, ~$60 for family)
-parental leave (don't remember how much time, but maternal and paternal)
cons: while the salary is higher than the national average for postdocs, it's still pretty tough to live in the Bay Area on that salary. Professors can choose to pay you more (that's allowed per the contract), but many choose to pay the minimum. Other issues are the same as other schools - minimal intervention by the university on issues of workplace harassment or just general poor working conditions.

review_title: Good place to work, benefits could be better.
job_title: Postdoctoral Researcher in UC Berkeley, CA
pros: Reputation and colleagues and its a nice place to live.  Campus is nice food close by.  Transportation to campus is pretty good with BART and numerous bus stops nearby.  Well integrated with lawrence berkeley national lab.
cons: The benefits pacakge is weak.  No contribution toward retirement from the university.  No matching.  Investment options limited by arrangement with Fidelity.  There are many layers of bureaucracy that results in complication and lack of info being transmitted from orghanization to organization.  It is not an efficient machine.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Berkeley, CA
pros: The staff and faculty are dynamic and caring.  As a graduate student researcher and instructor I felt supported by the professors I worked for as well as by the staff in my department.  The people at Berkeley are passionate about what they do and embody the values of diversity and inclusion that Berkeley strives to attain.
cons: Berkeley is a large bureaucracy and sometimes you encounter people with a very bureaucratic way of doing things.  Graduate student workers are also notoriously underpaid, although I believe conditions would be much worse without the active involvement of the union.

review_title: Diverse place to work with lots of career growth potential
pros: Very diverse, international student, faculty and staff; beautiful campus with trees, monuments, museums, libraries, recreational and cultural activities; lots of great off campus cafes, restaurants, books stores
cons: Lots of bureaucracy, politics, levels of administration and micro-cultures that can be either positive or negative, depending on how they are managed. Decent salaries, benefits and perks.

job_title: Welder in North Little Rock, AR
pros: It's a local job. It will pull you out of a hole, if that's what you need. If your a felon, it's the job for you. No offense.
cons: Low pay, raises for good employees hardly match rate of inflation. Working conditions are bad. It's very dirty, hot in the summer, and brutally cold in the winter.

review_title: Good benefits for GSIs...if you can handle the teaching load.
job_title: Graduate Student Instructor in Berkeley, CA
pros: The medical & counseling benefits for grad students are pretty good overall. The on-campus health center takes care of most of the basic check-ups, and refers you "out" if you need a specialist. There are lots of on-campus resources for growing your career skills as an academic.
cons: Working with students can be demanding of your time & energy! In a teaching assistant position, one has to be careful to draw firm boundaries to protect one's personal time.

review_title: Heartwarming students, but undeniably a bureaucracy
pros: The students are delightful and the faculty are world-class. Alumni love this place for a reason, or 100 reasons. Teaching, discoveries, summits, research, enhancement are all normal events.
cons: Difficult to earn a promotion, individuals with a strong interest in career progression must be very determined or find a great mentor and seek the next job on his/her own. Can be discouraging to see some coworkers focused on the retirement end-game rather than the opportunity to support our students. This seems trivial until you have to deal with it: commuting to campus is not easy, particularly if you drive and park here.

review_title: Flexible job, limited opportunities to move up
pros: My particular workplace has been very flexible with my hours both when I had small children and when I used the employee discount to go back and get my Master's degree.
cons: Berkeley tends to be divided into small fiefdoms with very little oversight. If you end up in a dysfunctional fiefdom with a bad boss, no one is watching and protecting the employees. This is something they are trying to work on, but it's still a factor. Also, at least in my case, I have a niche position in a small unit, so there are not obvious ways to move up.

job_title: Student Library Security in UC Berkeley, CA
pros: As a library security monitor you had ample time to do schoolwork while at one of the security stations.
cons: A requirement to have the job is that you have to work at least 1 graveyard shift during finals. I understand the job is highly sought after for students, and this is the trade-off if you want the gig. The library needs to be open during this time. Would be nice to be able to opt-out of this during the most important time of the school year.

job_title: Student DeCal Facilitator in Berkeley, CA
pros: As a volunteer (but technically employed) position, I had no real qualms. Student led classes allows for anyone passionate enough about a certain subject to share their passion with their fellow peers. Massive flexibility with scheduling and class content only limited by the availability of vacant space and adviser oversight, of which was quite light and laissez-faire.
cons: Sometimes, the lack of oversight did result in deadlines that crept up in regards to course registration, but that is less of a con of the administration and more of a critique one's own knowledge of deadlines. Knowing important events related to the DeCal program was difficult to find, frequently relying on word of mouth.

job_title: Graduate Student Instructor in Berkeley, CA
pros: Tuition reimbursement as a graduate student.  Solid reputation of the university.  Opportunity to interact with top notch faculty and researchers.
cons: As a graduate student employee, you are very low in the pecking order.  It is not uncommon to go over the maximum number of allowable hours when grading assignments or exams.  Some departments seem to handle this better than others.

review_title: Academically and intellectually fulfilling, but disappointing if considering a career in academics
job_title: Graduate Student Instructor in Berkeley, CA
pros:
- Opportunity to engage with peers and faculty with similar academic interests. 
- Reduced cost of graduate education.
- If considering a career in academics, gives a good understanding of all factors involved.
cons:
- Onerous bureaucracy
- Unless course faculty is experienced, being a student instructor is difficult to manage within the allotted time
- Tendency to "get lost in the system"

review_title: Great Work/LIfe Balance, Compensation & Job Security Problematic
job_title: Data Systems Analyst in Berkeley, CA
pros:
The work/life balance is outstanding.
Flexible hours
Ability to take time off for family reasons
Many work from home multiple days
Low key work environment (most of the time)
Lots of PTO
Great benefits

review_title: Inspiring/stable work environment, with some expected layers of bureaucracy
pros: Working with smart and passionate students makes for a good reason to get up in the morning.  Salary is of course lower than in private sector, but it's comfortable and has good benefits.  I worked for Haas, which has a pretty positive organizational culture and great leadership at the moment.
cons: I didn't necessarily feel as connected with the greater university community as much as my individual unit.  This wasn't necessarily a terrible thing--it just points out the inherent difficulty of working for an institution that has many layers to it, all the way up to UC Regents.

review_title: UC Berkeley Extension: Unique Mix of Commerce and Service to Community
pros:
Cooperative co-workers with not a lot of personal agenda setting and office politics. 
Interesting and interested coworkers who by and large like their jobs. 
Supportive management with a fair amount of transparency.

Unique mix of commerce (making money for the state) and service to the community (providing opportunities for students to learn, grown and achieve).
cons:
More standardized training for new hires would be great. 
Not a great place for advancement because there's not a lot of movement.

pros: The pay as a work study student is very fair, and because it's a university, supervisors are always very understanding about needing to take time off for midterms and classes. Employers are generally very open to schedule changes, and take any changes in stride. Overall, everyone is very flexible and understanding. Also, because this is academia, the staff are very friendly people.
cons: Depending on where you work, the environment can be very quiet, which can get dull some times. Also, as a student, a lot of the work is often administrative, so you have to be proactive in looking for more substantial opportunities within your job.

review_title: World class university only hampered by California's budget crisis.
pros: As most already know, this is a world class institution with access to some of the finest facilities and brightest researchers & students in the world. Great people, exciting research what more is there to say?
cons:
-CA budget issues have tightened up spending and funding.
-Lack of central career guidance for students in some departments
-Typical administrative bureaucracy

review_title: Management sucks, understaffed, low pay; incredible collection & staff
pros: UC Berkeley's Library is one of the greatest in the world. You can find anything, from the rarest to the most mundane, and the campus is alive with wonderful energy from a multicultural student body, off-campus scholars.
cons: The Library's administrators are narrow-minded, mean-spirited, cost-cutting jerks. Morale among staff is as low as it has ever been. review_title: Stellar public university has lost its light, become neoliberal corporation, eating & exploiting grad students' souls
pros: Beautiful weather, great area food, (for now) prestigious name on the CV, a few wonderful peers
cons: Toxic campus environment that protects sexual harassers and abusers, funnels police resources into stifling free speech rather than stopping violence, and engenders cruel competition to diminishing funding for academic endeavors while management rakes in higher and higher salaries.

review_title: Best public university in the world--possibly best university
pros: great colleagues, great city, great weather--the best intellectual community that I can imagine. I only hope that its alumni/ae and the state of California will continue to support it so that Berkeley can be Berkeley.

job_title: Asset Manager in UC Berkeley, CA

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Berkeley, CA
pros: People are very friendly, very smart and very willing to learn new things, or teach things to others. Compensation in the sciences is pretty good, and if you look hard enough you can find fellowships.

review_title: Nice environment and friendly workers at UC Botanical Garden

review_title: Great department but it’s everyone else that’s the problem.
pros: Comfortable environment and good perks appear from time to time. Take advantage of the tuition reimbursement for the extension program.
cons: Compensation is problematic, given the market. Also - there’s no tuition reimbursement for the actual university.

job_title: NSF MSPRF in UC Berkeley, CA
pros: I've really enjoyed doing research at U.C. Berkeley. There are tons of fascinating people to talk to and learn from. The department administration is great to work with and are extremely supportive. There is a constant stream of visitors, both to Berkeley and the nearby MSRI; so nearly anyone you'd like to talk to comes through on a semi-regular basis.

Office doors are usually closed, and most faculty don't attend tea time. So one needs to be fairly pro-active about meeting and starting conversations.

review_title: Get into the right department (the one with stable funding)
job_title: Project Policy Analyst in Berkeley, CA
pros:

review_title: If you want to get ahead, don't stay in one position on campus more that 3 years
pros: Being part of a system that can help the Bay Area and in many cases the world a better place.

review_title: Great and flexible on campus job tutoring athletes.

review_title: Great place to have a comfortable work-life balance, but not a good choice for ambitious employees.

review_title: Berkeley is a great place to work with a few challenges.
pros:
Working at UC Berkeley provides the employee with a real sense of community and a tangible connection to the education that is shaping the thinking of tomorrow's leaders. Whether you lean left, center, or right politically, you can generally connect with individuals or groups that share your values. Depending on your position and the work you are performing, UC Berkeley can have a very seasonal workload that is relatively light in the summers. The campus also observes most holidays which makes it easy to take time off for travel or whatever you prioritize in life. 

There are lots of training and development opportunities at UC Berkeley. If you are enterprising you can take advantage of these opportunities to further your career development.
cons:
UC Berkeley is a monolithic bureaucracy. Everywhere you turn there are forms or policies. Depending on where you work this can stifle career advancement because it's just too difficult to promote, or reclassify an employee. It's also nearly impossible to get an appropriate raise at the University because the Cost of Living Adjustments are not automatic (they depend upon the state legislature and governor) and equity increases are exceedingly rare.

Another thing that stands in the way of advancement is that for every energetic, ambitious, and capable person working at UC Berkeley, there is another who is what I consider to be a "lifer". They lack motivation, interest, and (sometimes) ability. Since there aren't a lot of carrot's to offer as incentives to these employees, most managers attempt to manage performance. pros: Great team mates. Like-minded people who are passionate about their work and believe in providing top-tier support to their campus clients. I made lifelong friends working here.

Bureaucracy (UCOP) within bureaucracy (campus) within bureaucracy (CSS) is a lot of layers to navigate through to accomplish even the smallest improvements.

There is a huge issue with younger "Millennial" employees; older employees openly (jokingly?) blame Millennials on changing workforce priorities, extremely high turnover, and frustrations with management. review_title: Great people but poor support for graduate students.
pros:
1. You'll be able to interact with brilliant and collaborative faculty and students. 
2. There are also plenty of funding opportunities if you're willing to work at them (e.g., teaching).
3. If you're a graduate student who knows exactly what you want to research and you can self-organize, self-instruct, and hold your own... Odds are that you'll do fine. You're also a rare student. 
4. You might also get an advisor willing to guide you through the program and perhaps even provide you advanced statistical/technical training. In this case, odds are that you'll also do fine.
5. Berkeley is a lovely and interesting place to live.
cons:
Simply put: inconsistency in mentor quality and a lack of coherent scaffolding for graduate students. 

Most graduate students have a sense of the topic they want to study. However, they're getting a degree because they want to be mentored in the techniques/topics of the field. They go to grad school to learn how to do research - not because they're already experts. 

The Berkeley Psych program suffers first from inconsistency in mentors. Some are awesome and some are horrifyingly bad (even, in my opinion, abusive of their students). This could be countered by having a strong support system for students, good course offerings (especially statistical/technical training), clear milestones students must achieve to progress to their PhD, and pressure on mentors to actively encourage the progress of their students.

Graduate support, in spite of efforts on the part of some nifty faculty, remained inconsistent as of Fall 2012. This was hampered in part by continuous turnover in our support staff. The end result, however, is that there isn't really a strong community in place advocating on behalf of the psych grad students or providing resources to guide them.

Statistical/technical training is shallow, lasting only the first year and focusing on only the most general frequentist techniques (unless you happen to have an advisor willing to mentor you in techniques more specific to your own research).

There is a milestones document but (1) it has been revised often enough that it's confusing as to what it's in it and (2) mentors are inconsistent about their opinion of it. Some ignore it almost entirely while others help students build and stick to plans to follow it. 

In other words, mentors don't really appear to receive much feedback based on student performance. If a student gets lost in the cracks - or even if several do - then it's on the students. This makes the motivation low for mentors to actively help students plan for and progress towards milestones. This is not that unreasonable given that mentors are busy faculty with active research programs, teaching loads, and their own personal lives but disappointing if you're a bewildered graduate student.

I can't personally recommend the Berkeley Psychology department as a good place to be a graduate student. However, your experience will vary pending your own disposition and the mentor you align with.

If you get a raise or promotion it's usually because you know someone that likes you but rarely has anything to do with your actual accomplishments. If you're a young white male you'll have no problems. Women and POC have to work 10X harder to get anywhere and unless they can find someone to mentor and fight for them, they will never get anywhere or will get replaced by someone else as soon as they speak up.
