If you ask for help, you become an instant target, even if you have the best of intentions and do it in a professional manner. It's the most unhealthy and unprofessional place I've ever worked in. I was told that I handled everything in an extremely professional manner but it didn't matter.  If you become a target the university has way too much power and money to crush anyone who speaks up in any way and supervisors know that. I have so many colleagues that have left or are leaving due to this unhealthy work environment and would never go back. - Working on cutting edge research

- Feels extremely rewarding
cons:
- Often pressured into working long extra hours
- Not much of a work/play balance, but that's sort of to be expected

pros: University of California Berkeley is the best place to work in since you may have chance to work with very smart scientists. My position supported by the funding that my supervisor obtained. It is nice place to work.
cons: University of California Berkeley may not be your best choice if you are looking for higher salary. (of course, exclude professor position)

pros: The Berkeley campus is beautiful and easy to get to. The high caliber of students evident across campus and exciting to be a part of.
cons: The UC system has received large budget cut in the past few years and it has a direct impact of student services and the student experience.  It can be difficult to get what you want to do accomplished with limited resources.

pros: Post-doctoral support systems were in place, functioning, and extremely professional. I would specially like to mention - the International Office, Career Center, and the Berkeley postdoctoral association. Post docs have full access to the career services; which is a boon for international students seeking industry placements or career change from academia to the professional services industry. The International Office is staffed with extremely competent and professional staff.
cons: Graduated post docs don't have the same privileges as a graduating student (i.e., I had a humbling experience with the Alumni Association on LinkedIn).

pros: Great opportunity for students looking for part-time work on campus. Supervisors were kind, consistent and approachable.  Day/evening shifts are flexible and structured around student-workers' class schedules. ETS also hosts end-of-semester networking parties that introduce student workers to opportunities in its other departments.  It was definitely a rewarding and non-stressful "first job" experience.
cons: Nature of position requires long treks around the hilly campus with a bulky equipment pack. This can get a bit tiring and tedious, but it's still fun & doable if you know what to expect.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Berkeley, CA
pros: It's an enjoyable academic environment to work at and while there is a fair amount of stress and long working hours, the science done here is world class. In addition, even though it's highly competitive, people are quite friendly and helpful which is unusual for a world class university.
cons: Obviously as a graduate student or postdoc, you are paid well below value, but it is an excellent training program as well.

job_title: Administrative Assistant II in Berkeley, CA
pros: A lot of diversity, various on campus and local events, ability to see change from year to year, most employees are very helpful.
cons: UC Berkeley can be known to have a lot of red tape and circles that you have to run around in. Some things are slow to change. Hourly rate employees are paid sometime around the eighth of the month.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Berkeley, CA
pros: UC, Berkeley has good research facilities and world class scientists.  Every graduate program is highly regarded, so you are surrounded by extremely smart and motivated students.  It is well connected to lawrence berkeley national lab, which provides for more research opportunities
cons: Budget cuts have affected services.  Stipend is well below average and you live in an expensive (and amazingly fun) part of the country.

review_title: Great Research, Mediocre Classes, Hands Off Management
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Berkeley, CA
pros: You will find lots of creative freedom for research and many nice people and easy collaborations.  This is a top notch school, and the facilities are world class.  Beautiful campus as well.
cons: Classroom instruction can be pretty poor and even your research adviser will usually be too busy to meet with students more than a few times per month.  Expect to solve a lot of problems on your own and being a self starter is a must, there is no hand holding here.

pros: I think there are some nice benefits if you happen to become a GSI or a professor. That is when money starts to roll in. Your tuition is paid plus a stipend each year.
cons: The salary for undergraduate students and the more menial jobs is quite low, in fact, by 2016, the majority of students' salaries will be at minimum wage.

job_title: Academic Service Assistant in Berkeley, CA
pros: Really chill job, you get to use the facilities when no one is around. Also you get free printing. It serves a basic function that requires you to know how to use and fix printers in the center, but that's about it.
cons: The low pay means that you have to put in alot of work hours to get a decent salary. However that being said most of the people who work hours end up studying during the time anyway; you take out as much as you put in!

job_title: Undergraduate Student Instructor in UC Berkeley, CA
pros: Experience working with people who are the greatest in their field, whether they be at the university itself or partnered. Challenge yourself to master content which you should know.
cons: Caliber of students is demanding on preparation. Workload fairly heavy for the amount of compensation, but the rewards outweigh these difficulties.

review_title: Peer Adviser in College of Letters & Sciences
pros: Flexible schedule, supportive environment, understand that you are a student and allow you to prioritize school, good pay, allows work study as well. You really learn how to think on your feet and they give great leadership opportunities, such as leading Major Planning workshops.
cons: None from my experience! I loved working here and found that the values of the university were well implemented in the program. Allowed me to grow and work under pressure as well as familiar myself with the school's policies.

pros: Great mentorship opportunities and plenty of spaces to grow. Perks are pretty nice. a strong community for student affairs and academic advising.
cons: The information systems can be complicated and inefficient to use when working with students. So many offices and department to navigate--but once you know people in offices, it is easier to route communication and such processes.

review_title: Great research reputation but be prepared for low pay (standard for postdocs)
pros:
Intellectually stimulating environment
Hard-working and dedicated colleagues
Access to great resources (classes and trainings, professional development workshops for postdocs, career and job search resources, library system)
Great research reputation (name recognition and prestige)
Pretty impressive that as a public institution Cal manages to stay competitive with other top universities despite having significantly fewer resources and funds
cons:
Low, low pay (but seems standard across universities; appears comparable to postdoc salaries at Stanford and Harvard)
No work-life balance
Postdocs are worked really hard (and there's always pressure to do more)

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Berkeley, CA
pros: Resources, people and academic programs are all top notch - amazing experience.
cons: Graduate students and postdocs are not treated like real employees - poor health care, poor retirement programs.  They use loopholes like telling us we work 49% time to prevent access to full benefits, even though we work closer to 150% time - should be illegal in my opinion.

review_title: Research position within the mechanical engineering department
pros: UC Berkeley's reputation is among the best benefits of conducting research at Cal.  Depending on the specific research group, the work can be incredibly satisfying as well
cons: Working as a researcher at Berkeley often involved dealing with rather large egos, as most everyone was at the top of their field.

review_title: Wonderful community in some ways, but also a lot of disfunction and mediocrity.
job_title: Student Academic Advisor II in Berkeley, CA
pros: Some brilliant, hardworking, passionate people.  Some awesome, inspiring students and faculty.  Beautiful work environment (campus), decent benefits, perks of being in a university setting and occasionally going to lectures.  Also perks like being able to use the on-campus art studio!
cons: Huge bureaucracy, lot's of disfunction, lot's of unevenness in terms of the skills and competencies of other staff.  Often felt that higher level administration had no idea what was going on, didn't listen, didn't care.

pros:
- Close to UC Berkeley Campus and BART
- Great training for data management and prospect research
- Good learning opportunity for fundraising and development
cons:
- tedious work at times, but it comes with the territory 
- Low prospects for promotion
- Grunt work, grunt work, grunt work (again, part of the territory.

pros: Casual environment, professional development opportunities, good benefits, progressive environment.
cons: Salaries within Equity and Inclusion are definitely not reflective of all that the jobs require, severely lacking in administrative support and processes, feels like you are working at a nonprofit, vast disparities between this division and the well-funded richer division such as the Business School.

pros: As a peer advisor I was able to meet great friends while working and was motivated by those around me. The hours were flexible and the experience of working in a team was just amazing.
cons: Not enough available work hours due to insufficient need for peer advisors. I would of enjoyed having more duties and responsibilities.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Berkeley, CA
pros: Good work environment as a graduate student.  The community is extremely supportive and the professors in my department are good mentors with few exceptions.  Healthy work/life balance is encouraged.  Pay is low for the bay, but above average for a graduate student.
cons: Turnover is ridiculous for the administrators in the department.  There is a core group of good staff who have been there for ages, but everyone else doesn't last for more than a year.  It's frustrating to not know who to contact.

pros: Working at the ticket office was a good experience . Working at the ticket office wasn't very hard. On the other hand I didn't gain any skills . Watching games for free was a good experience. Overall great
cons: Low pay and not enough cool stuff to do. I would rather have done more stuff and contributed more. Will call was boring.

pros: Parker Metal bellow , very good company to work , I learn a lot experience from aerospace and a lot of overtime and very good manager and very good benefit very good people I work with
cons: I feel bad Parker Metal Bellow no longer company at Moorpark , if the company sold to other company I still have my job, I do a lot of work welding chamber , I like to work at Parker Hannifin

pros: It's a prestigious school with lots of smart people. If you are stuck in a problem and need help, you will most likely get it.
cons: Unless you want to pursue an academic career, UC Berkeley is not the best place to work. You expect either teaching or grading papers.

pros: The University is a wonderful place to work. It is a dynamic and forward thinking employer due to the many different cultures of its student/faculty make up. The campus is beautiful and fun to explore. There is much to see and interesting to walk amongst the students. The sense of energy and intellectual proximity is unique in the Bay Area.
cons: If commuting on BART has some challenges, especially if service is disrupted. There is no easy way back over the bay. Also panhandling can be depressing and constant.

pros:
-- It is a good experience to practice communication skills.
-- They offer competitive bonuses if you did well.
cons:
-- It sometimes make people fall asleep if no one is picking up the phones from the other side for a long time.
-- Not all conversations are pleasant because people are not usually happy to talk to me.

review_title: Great People. Big Visibility. Low Pay.
pros: The benefits are great, and once you are in, it is hard to lose your job there. The people are great to work with, very low politics except from above. It is state-run, so the pay is much lower than other companies, but the benefits are great, and there is a great live/work balance. Lots of holidays and time off.
cons: Politics, subject to layoffs, low pay.

pros: Students are passionate.  Academic environment and student culture are intellectually engaging.  Some staff are passionate and fantastic.  Good transit benefits.
cons: Pay that is not competitive with the rest of the Bay Area.  Long hours without appreciation of work nor of the desire to have a life outside of work.  Inflexibility in working hours.  Students who can make or break your career based upon whether they like you.  Directive department heads who are unwilling to hear feedback.  No tuition benefits.   Claim to be innovative, but as a staff member you see that nearly everything is antiquated and people don't want to change from "it's always been done that way."

pros: Lots of resources!  Labs are generally well-equipped, and Lawrence Berkeley National Labs has an amazing amount of money and expertise.
cons: Very few professional development opportunities.  IT infrastructure is split between a million different systems with poorly-defined boundaries.  With the funding cuts, Berkeley's best days may be behind it.

review_title: Great place to work if you don't like challenge
pros: Perks and benefits are pretty good but salary is still not competitive. I love that I can access public lectures by renowned researchers, authors, and Nobel laureates. It's also a beautiful campus to work in.
cons: Staff experience can vary by individual departments and depends a lot on the leadership. My experience has not included high quality leadership. Given the condition of the state budget and possible future layoffs, staff morale is low and salaries are not competitive.

review_title: Good place but you can't move up without applying to new jobs in different departments.
job_title: Program Advisor in UC Berkeley, CA
pros: Nice benefits, including three weeks off per year and good health benefits. But, lots of old, unhappy people work at UC Berkeley.
cons: Lack of upward mobility. You'll need to be cut throat to stand out.

job_title: Student Affairs Coordinator in Oakland, CA
pros: Beautiful campus, smart students, decent benefits. I have met many great, kind, and passionate people (both colleagues and students) here. Unfortunately there are challenges at the institutional level.
cons: It's a large, silo-ed organization. One hand doesn't always know what the other is doing, which leads to redundancies and confusion. All departments operate pretty autonomously, so there is discrepancy in terms of experience--some places on campus are great to work, others are not. Working in student affairs is seen as "lesser" than academics by many on campus.

job_title: Graduate Student Instructor in Berkeley, CA
pros: Fee remission is a very good deal.
cons: Teaching a single discussion section can take as much time as enrolling in two additional classes.  You will have lesson planning and preparation, the time actually in the classroom, office hours, and grading.

job_title: Cart Driver in UC Berkeley, CA
pros: Great student job to earn extra money while studying. Minimal job training required. Flexible scheduling. Can pick up as many open shifts as desired. Meet other students outside of field of study.
cons: Shifts can drag if client intake is slow. Compensation is pretty much minimum wage. Marginal page increase if promoted to a student supervisor position. Some shifts are moderately stressful.

job_title: Marketing Coordinator in UC Berkeley, CA
pros: Great work-life balance and low stress. You are moving with the campus's pace. Though the salary isn't competitive, I do miss the days I used to work for the campus as my job didn't trickle into my personal life.
cons: Usually, there is a lot of bureaucratic tape around how things are handled. A lot of paperwork and legacy software.

review_title: Lab facilities are adequate, but there is not a strong "group" culture. You might as well be working alone.
pros: Broad exposure to different areas of chemistry and chemical engineering.
cons: Professors run large groups. They are more involved with raising the funds to support these group than they are in the research (95%:5% time). Little guidance is offered. If you work on a project that is related to an ongoing (successful) project in the lab, your labmates may be able to help get you up to speed.

job_title: GIS/Remote Sensing Lab Assistant in Berkeley, CA
pros:
- very flexible hours
- quite a bit of independent work, but great for practicing good time management
- campus is beautiful, what can I say
cons: - I really cannot say there are any real downsides, given campus is not that large. Maybe the fact that my supervisors office was 7 minute bike ride away

review_title: I love working here so much
pros: It is a beautiful parklike place to work, the people are super bright, polite, funny, kind and cool (almost all the time). There is just a wonderful sense of mission and identity. They pay well, are not uptight, no C students running ish around here!
cons: It is hard to get fully staffed because the area is expensive to live in and we get poached by private industry paying more, or people can't afford to move here to take jobs.

pros: If you are looking for a place to retire with a good retirement plan and ready to wait 30 for it then you can't go wrong.
cons: Not efficient environment, lack of communication between departments, double standards (some are hypocritical). All of it is present in UC. I don't think any of it is extreme as it can be, but unpleasant for sure. UC Berkeley feels rigid outside of the flexibility scope it set for itself.

job_title: Student Assistant III in Berkeley, CA
pros: I think the best thing about working at the Student Affairs Development Office was that it was very relaxed in comparison to a lot of other offices.
cons: Honestly, I can't think of anything bad to say about this office or the group of people there. They are all wonderful and I wish all offices could be like them. They love each other.

review_title: Good Place for a student to work.
job_title: Student Library Employee in Berkeley, CA
pros: Flexible hours, which is clutch when you have projects, tests etc to work on during the school year. Supervising staff is great training was easy and straightforward.
cons: Pay was ok but not enough to really save anything with, but I was also a part time student employee so thats expected.

review_title: A place where one can learn about computer basics and also get a good experience with costumer service.
pros: The management team is very friendly and would help out lab assistants in any may possible. Scheduling is also flexible and suitable for college students.
cons: Often times senior consultants might be micro-managing without knowing what they are doing themselves. The everyday duties can be too boring.

pros: Great place to work especially if you are student. Schedule is fairly flexible and will allow for exams. Got see a different side of my professors.
cons: Pay should be improved. I was never mentored by any of my employers. I feel mentoring should be required as the purpose of college is to prepare students for the working world. Interviewing process is haphazard and inconsistent.

review_title: Grad students kind of get shafted
pros: The campus and area are beautiful, and the professors have impressive research collaborations that extend far beyond the confines of the university itself.
cons: Departments lack supporting staff that would help allow professors' time to be spent more on mentoring students than on dealing with administrative crap. The financial system of the entire university is a nightmare.

pros: Generally speaking, decent pay. There's a strong team atmosphere and the position is somewhat flexible. Flexible hours. Minimum wage at UC Berkeley is pretty good.
cons: Payroll system is a little bit difficult and convoluted. The hours can be somewhat bizarre as a result of the nature of the business (offering classes to grade school-aged children).

job_title: Study Strategies and Time Management Peer Mentor (Tutor) in UC Berkeley, CA
pros:
- they are very flexible and work around your class schedule
- you can take time off when emergency arises (must leave town, exam approaches, etc...)
- you learn a lot about SS & TM on the job
- you have a little time to study while at work
cons: - the pay could have been slightly better

pros: meet a lot of people, wonderful people. There are so many interesting research going on at berkeley, just join one, see if you like it or not.
cons: course are a little bit hard. sometimes, I think I need to have a little bit time for meself not just school work school work.

review_title: Great place to be a postdoc
pros: Good benefits, access to world class scientists and seminars, proximity to biotech, PIEP and BPEP programs for postdocs interested in industry jobs
cons: It's a postdoc (not a "real" job), pay is controlled by feds (NIH) so it's low for the cost of living in the area, hours can be long

review_title: Perspective of a 5th year graduate student at UC Berkeley
job_title: Graduate Student in UC Berkeley, CA
pros: Academic Freedom. You can research what you want without many restrictions. The teachers are knowledgeable and there are a lot of outreach opportunities to explore.
cons: Not much guidance. You can go years without anything working and nobody really helps you. This is bad if you require a good mentor.

job_title: Student Consultant in UC Berkeley, CA
pros:
I worked part time as a computer consultant while attending school at UC Berkeley.

- Great opportunities for gaining experience while in school
- Thorough training and growth opportunities
- Flexible hours and level of engagement - you get as much out of the position as you put in
- Great co-workers and boss
- As the workforce consists mostly of students, plenty of opportunities for promotions
cons: Definitely not the manager or the department's fault, but budget cuts in the school system forced cuts in hours.

review_title: Good environment, beware of the cost of living
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Berkeley, CA
pros: Challenging environment with top professors, career opportunities are excellent in engineering. Academia/Industry relations are pretty strong. Lots of people from different cultures.
cons: pay is ridiculously low for a GSI. GSR is a bit above, but given the cost of living in the area, you won't be able to live well.

pros:
Good health benefits, except maternity leave.
Decent scientific resources: equipment, people
Overall positive environment, beautiful campus
cons: Maternity leave policy is immediate 3/4 pay for 6 weeks, after which you receive no more payment without returning back to work full time. If, as a postdoc, your position is up for renewal (as it is every 2 years) you will not be renewed and you will lose your pay and health insurance promptly after having a child. This is actually pretty horrible, and Berkeley should fix this.

job_title: Clinical Program Assistant in Berkeley, CA
pros: Worked with truly talented folks who are efficient at what they do and kind to people around them. I was lucky to have such an amazing group of people to work with at the Clinical Program. The events the law school holds and the awesome guest speakers who visit: fabulous! Another perk: Berkeley Law can never go wrong with their choice of catering.
cons: None that I can think of. The Clinical Program staff is truly excellent.

pros: Work at a beautiful campus with awesome trees and walking opportunities. Great healthcare and retirement benefits.  Good work life balance.
cons: Very hierarchical, slow moving, and it is hard to grow professionally.  People tend to stay so there isn't much opportunity to move up.  To get ahead you need to check the job postings and move to get a pay raise.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Berkeley, CA
pros: creative, free environment where one can explore ideas they have for their research.  Beautiful campus and lots of great places to work and study all over.
cons: not much money to live in the expensive bay area; a lot of your perks or time-off policies seem to depend on who your advisor is.  My advisor is fair- but also has high expectations (perfect balance, I think).

pros: The people I was working with were really great and we got along really well. The hours were easy and so was the work.
cons: Not much to say here, just because everything was so flexible. I guess the one thing I can say is that the work would sometimes get too mundane.

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in San Francisco, CA
pros: Seemingly unlimited resources for research opportunities, access to equipment, and world renowned faculty. It seems that external funding more accessible at a university with such prestige.
cons: Living in the bay area is really expensive. Some feel that the pay is not proportional to the work and that the stress felt while trying to deal with the cost of living may hinder productivity.

review_title: Great launching pad into a corporate job
pros: Most people who work there are very educated and liberal.  Excellent benefits, many which are non-standard such as free museum admission.  Lots of cheap dining options.  Great work life balance.  Lots of holidays.
cons: Poor cash compensation.  Parking is difficult and expensive.  Very limited opportunities for title changes and raises.  Office stations and computers are often outdated.

review_title: Postdoc in the group of Martin Head-Gordon
pros: Work with some of the smartest people in the world. Most people are very friendly and everyone is relaxed. Things are very Berkeley throughout. Find out yourself what exactly that means :-)
cons: It's hard to say anything about UC Berkeley that I didn't like, although this might only hold true for the particular group I worked with. I have heard that other groups are less relaxed but that is actually hard to believe for me.

review_title: Berkeley is definitely of=ne of the best place to do science
pros: You get access to the best people in your field and also people at the Lawrence Berkeley Lab. The overall atmosphere is positive with the pulse on the next big thing in science.
cons: If you do not work in a group, then it can be a challenge to find enough people to collaborate with. But ultimately depnds on your communication skills as there is dearth of good scientist to collaborate with.

review_title: Working in a large university system is disconnected from the real world.
pros: Prestigious name, decent benefits. Potential for fulfilling work, depending on what you are doing and the department in which you work.
cons: Management is exceptionally weak. Most managers in location in which I work have been there for decades and moved up to management positions. No one has gained any effective management experience. I've experienced and witnessed unethical and illegal behavior.

review_title: If you're in the right department you'll work with the most empathetic, wonderful, friendliest people on the planet.
pros: Flexible schedule with a people first attitude. Very good benefits (talk to HR to find the best plan).
cons: Working in research can sometimes mean long, grueling hours to meet deadlines. Not much room to move up, internally, in certain fields.

review_title: Awesome place to work, students, staff & faculty one big family.
job_title: Student Services Representative in UC Berkeley, CA
pros: The work force is so diversified every nationality is represented on  campus in some way I.e. student, staff, faculty, visiting scholars etc.. Just an amazing place to have been a part of for over 17 years.
cons: I have none it was truly a growing experience.

pros: UC is the biggest employer in the state. Most departments have basic 9-5 hours, people actually go home at 5. Benefits are pretty good, but you're experience would depend on what department you're applying too. There's a pension system if you get a career position, vests after 5 years.
cons: Salaries are not high and UC is a huge bureaucracy. The pension system can actually keep people stuck in their jobs, just waiting for retirement. So sometimes the experience is not that dynamic.

review_title: Good location, prestigious track record in research, low pay, old infrastructure, very slow and tiring bureaucracy.
pros: In the Bay Area, close to hi-tech companies. State of the art research, but not in all labs. Lots of extracurricular activities.
cons: Not much interaction among peers, hostile competition even within the same labs. Insufficient housing, low pay. a lot of wannabes who come here just for the name of the institution, poor management of financial resources... also you are a third class citizen if you're a postdoc.

review_title: Good place for a starting job but not much upward mobility
job_title: Marketing Coordinator in UC Berkeley, CA
pros: Flexible scheduling, good training, and fellow employees are nice! Very good work/life balance and you're not expected to do anything if you're not on the clock.
cons: Too bureaucratic, everything takes forever in order to get approved. There are a bunch of forms needed to be filled out even for the smallest event. Not much upward mobility

review_title: Great funding to do research (bad compensation), competitive environment, project with lack of practical application.
pros: Great benefits, a great learning experience surrounded with very knowledgeable and competitive people.
cons: Absence of work-life balance, compensation for a postdoctoral appointment and living in the Bay Area is too low. I had a baby during my stay at Berkeley and the evaluation of my performance was unfair and non-ethical.

review_title: A fairly typical job, but short shifts and lack of parking is problematic.
job_title: Student Food Service Worker in Berkeley, CA
pros: The food options, both on and off campus, are pretty good. There are periods of slowness where you can do pretty much whatever you want.
cons: Lack of nearby parking meant I would have to spend my break running to my car to fill the meter. Even then, sometimes I would get ticketed which would annihilate most of my paycheck for the day.

review_title: PhD Researcher having completed 5 years at Berkeley
job_title: Anonymous Employee in UC Berkeley, CA
pros: Collaboration between labs and meeting interesting people. Lots of equipment and opportunities to learn. Beautiful campus and great location. Great health care system for students.
cons: Highly bureaucratic. Pay as a graduate student depends heavily on your parent department. Don't expect to make much money. Advisors can often leave a lot to be desired, but there are several shining stars.

job_title: Team Lead Accountant in Pleasanton, CA
pros: Great Benefits, offers pension, medical and dental is paid for by the company.
cons: Management is old school, does not like changes even if its for efficiency

job_title: Technical Project Management Professional in Berkeley, CA
pros: Lots of smart people, lots of projects going on, and also looks great on the resume.  Overall, Berkeley is a very good place to work at.
cons: Can be hard to network between other departments, frequently feel siloed in my home department.  Also navigating the administration, red tape, paperwork, etc, is always a hassle!
